content.webTitle: H&M billionaire Stefan Persson buys Hampshire village for £25m

fields.headline: H&M billionaire Stefan Persson buys Hampshire village for £25m
fields.bodyText: Money may not buy you happiness, but as Stefan Persson, the Swedish billionaire owner of fashion giant H&M, is discovering, it can buy you an awful lot of property. Not content with 8,500 acres of country estate in Wiltshire, Persson is planning to bolster his sizeable property portfolio by snapping up an entire English village. The world's 16th-richest man is preparing to buy the 2,000 acre Linkenholt estate near Andover, Hampshire, for £25m. It comes complete with an Edwardian-style manor house, 1,500 acres of farmland, a 425-acre wood, a cricket ground and 21 cottages leased to villagers. According to property sources the deal follows an intense bidding war with other wealthy would-be buyers, undaunted by the turbulent property market. Persson, whose wealth is estimated at £11.4bn, is thought to have had an offer accepted at the top end of the £23-25m guide price. Since the 1970s, the estate – which was put up for sale in March – has been run by a charitable trust after its last owner, Herbert Blagrave, an entrepreneur, died childless. Rents for properties range from £500 a month for a modest cottage to £3,500 for the manor house. Shooting rights should also prove lucrative for the 61-year-old fashion tycoon, who counts the king and queen of Sweden among his friends. Persson, who last hit the headlines when he cancelled Kate Moss's modelling contract with H&M following allegations about her drug use, also owns a £9m country estate near Marlborough in Wiltshire. H&M, or Hennes & Mauritz, was founded by Persson's father, Erling, in 1947, and has more than 1,800 stores across the world.
